title: Work - Change in KE over two distances

content.question: A constant force <math alttext="F sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> is exerted continuously on a block that is initially at rest on a horizontal surface. The change in kinetic energy of the block while the block is moved from position <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> to <math alttext="x equals 50 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>50</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></math> is <math alttext="delta K sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, and the change in kinetic energy of the block as the block is moved from <math alttext="x equals 50 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>50</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></math> to <math alttext="x equals 100 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></math> is <math alttext="delta K sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. How does <math alttext="delta K sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> compare to <math alttext="delta K sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, and why?

choices.label: <math alttext="delta K sub 2, equals delta K sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> because the velocity increases by the same amount between <math alttext="0 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math> to <math alttext="50 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>50</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math> and between <math alttext="50 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>50</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math> to <math alttext="100 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>100</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math>.

<math alttext="delta K sub 2, equals delta K sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> because the applied force does the same work on the block between <math alttext="0 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math> to <math alttext="50 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>50</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math> and between <math alttext="50 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>50</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math> to <math alttext="100 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>100</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math>.

<math alttext="delta K sub 2, is greater than delta K sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> because the block is moving faster on average between <math alttext="50 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>50</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math> to <math alttext="100 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>100</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math> than it is between <math alttext="0 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math> to <math alttext="50 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>50</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math>.

<math alttext="delta K sub 2, is greater than delta K sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> because the rate of change of kinetic energy is greater between <math alttext="50 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>50</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math> to <math alttext="100 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>100</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math> than it is between <math alttext="0 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math> to <math alttext="50 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>50</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math>.

content.answer: <math alttext="delta K sub 2, equals delta K sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> because the applied force does the same work on the block between <math alttext="0 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math> to <math alttext="50 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>50</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math> and between <math alttext="50 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>50</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math> to <math alttext="100 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>100</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math>.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
